content.raw: Jenkins only shows the same test failure, `INTEGRATION_joint_screw`.
content.html: Jenkins only shows the same test failure, INTEGRATION_joint_screw.

content.raw: I found the minimal way to reproduce the issue. The world is not cleaned up properly if there is a link which is the child of 2 different joints. I'm still trying to find out if it's a problem in Gazebo or DART upstream. We weren't experiencing this before because destructors were not being called.
content.html: I found the minimal way to reproduce the issue. The world is not cleaned up properly if there is a link which is the child of 2 different joints. I'm still trying to find out if it's a problem in Gazebo or DART upstream. We weren't experiencing this before because destructors were not being called.

content.raw: This is a problem in DART, which is related to #913. We can avoid the segfault by the patch @chapulina [posted](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/671#issue-148775343), but I'm not sure if DART can pass the test because DART will ignore the closed loop constraint.
content.html: This is a problem in DART, which is related to #913. We can avoid the segfault by the patch @chapulina posted, but I'm not sure if DART can pass the test because DART will ignore the closed loop constraint.

content.raw: Thanks for the issue number, #1435 is also related.
content.html: Thanks for the issue number, #1435 is also related.

content.raw: As for DART passing the test, the test is currently being disabled halfway, so at least it loads the model without complaining. But this pull request revealed a problem during tear-down, so now I disabled the test all the way from the beginning in 77a2dd7.
content.html: As for DART passing the test, the test is currently being disabled halfway, so at least it loads the model without complaining. But this pull request revealed a problem during tear-down, so now I disabled the test all the way from the beginning in 77a2dd7.

content.raw: Ticketed upstream [issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/671) with DART and disabled the test 77a2dd7
content.html: Ticketed upstream issue with DART and disabled the test 77a2dd7

content.raw: Yup, the whole deletion process will be [refactored](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/insertion_deletion_flow/insertion_deletion_flow/insertion_deletion_flow.md?fileviewer=file-view-default) in Gazebo 8, so we'll have a chance to check these details.
content.html: Yup, the whole deletion process will be refactored in Gazebo 8, so we'll have a chance to check these details.

content.raw: About ABI compatibility - The [ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/302/API_ABI_report/) checker picked up 2 low severity warnings. Normally we try to keep the results clean but the changes to the vtable look minor (there is a behavior change from calling the `Fini` function). Maybe @\_jrivero\_  can comment on the severity of this ABI change.
content.html: About ABI compatibility - The ABI checker picked up 2 low severity warnings. Normally we try to keep the results clean but the changes to the vtable look minor (there is a behavior change from calling the Fini function). Maybe @_jrivero_ can comment on the severity of this ABI change.

content.raw: Oh thanks for seeing that, I saw the :large_blue_circle: and assumed there were no warnings.
content.html: Oh thanks for seeing that, I saw the :large_blue_circle: and assumed there were no warnings.

content.raw: Umm interesting. The two `+      public: virtual void Fini();` additions in `ODEJoint.hh` and `BulletJoint.hh` will make that old third party applications will call this new addition instead the previous `Base::Fini()`. Depending on your implementations and goals this can be fine or not. AFAIK, the memory footprint is not altered (just a change in the vtable) so we should not be in risk of serious problems usually assigned with broken ABIs (this is why probably is marked as Low).
content.html: Umm interesting. The two + public: virtual void Fini(); additions in ODEJoint.hh and BulletJoint.hh will make that old third party applications will call this new addition instead the previous Base::Fini(). Depending on your implementations and goals this can be fine or not. AFAIK, the memory footprint is not altered (just a change in the vtable) so we should not be in risk of serious problems usually assigned with broken ABIs (this is why probably is marked as Low).

content.raw: ok that's a little concerning... did you have to change the tests much for them to pass or are the changes within gazebo? that would give an idea how this affects user code.
content.html: ok that's a little concerning... did you have to change the tests much for them to pass or are the changes within gazebo? that would give an idea how this affects user code.

content.raw:
The changes were within Gazebo. Now we're calling destructors which had never been called, so we never realized they caused crashes. 

Some of these were picked up by tests and were fixed, see the changes to the DART joints for example. But if we didn't have a test for each of these joints, maybe we wouldn't have seen the problem. And when users deleted their models with joints, they would experience the crash. Note that this is independent of the ABI change.

So I think there is chance for regression, yes. Maybe that's a risk we don't want to take in a released version, so I can redirect the PR to default.
content.html:
The changes were within Gazebo. Now we're calling destructors which had never been called, so we never realized they caused crashes.

Some of these were picked up by tests and were fixed, see the changes to the DART joints for example. But if we didn't have a test for each of these joints, maybe we wouldn't have seen the problem. And when users deleted their models with joints, they would experience the crash. Note that this is independent of the ABI change.

So I think there is chance for regression, yes. Maybe that's a risk we don't want to take in a released version, so I can redirect the PR to default.

content.raw: ok we've got the ball rolling already so why not, approving.
content.html: ok we've got the ball rolling already so why not, approving.
